segments.text: It's the 18th of August, 1987.
We're in Terry Kahn's office, and I'm interviewing Sandy Rosenblum.
How do you want your name to appear on this document?
Is it Sandy?
No, it's really Sandra.
Sandra.
All right.
Sandra, you are being interviewed because you have been on the faculty here for some time and no one knows what you do.
We think it might be a good idea to get a handle on your activities.
No, I think I've done just fine without anyone knowing what I was doing.
Well, you're rarely here.
You're usually in circuit somewhere.
That's not quite true.
So in terms of the history of planning education in Texas, we're here to record your role.
I think the biggest role I have is that there's so many of my students that I share with everybody else.
Obviously, they're not uniquely my students.
Well, let's go back to the beginning.
What was your background before you came to UK?
I had a degree in political science, but between my master's degree and my doctorate, I dropped out.
I don't think dropped out is the right word.
I had not intended to go on for a PhD, and I went to work for a systems analysis firm in Santa Barbara.
They had just gotten Charlie Har with secretary of HUD, or undersecretary of HUD.
It was the end of the Johnson era, and there was a feeling that urban would have been successful.
There was all sorts of space technology, and there was a feeling that the space technology could be applied to urban systems.
And so for basically, you know, I used to call them World War III systems analysis firms that kind of did a lot of work for defense departments.
We're giving fairly large grants.
to look at urban transportation problems.
And the firm that I went to work for had nobody there who was not a World War III type.
And they moseyed down to UCLA and put up an ad, and I interviewed, and I went to work for them.
And I worked for them for a couple of years.
No, you did your doctoral work at UCLA.
At UCLA.
All three of my degrees are from UCLA.
Who did you study with?
John Jack Bowens, who is an expert on local government, especially district government.
Also, I did some work and was a TA for Fran Rabinowitz.
She's done a lot of things in her career.
She's a professor now at SC, and she's going to be here.
She's going to be the main speaker for the APA, the Texas Chapter APA Conference.
Mostly, I always focused on local government, so the fact that I didn't have a planning degree was not
and I'm here is not totally surprising.
I always was interested in local government and local planning issues, even though I wasn't in a planning school.
I got my master's in public administration, MPA, and then I went out into the workforce.
I quickly, I knew nothing much about transportation, but I was the only urban person on the team under this contract.
And our contract monitor at HUD was Leon Cole.
Uh-huh.
The plot thickens.
The plot thickens.
I did some real interesting work there.
Mostly I was a gopher when I was young.
I was by far the most junior person on the project.
The piece of work that I cut out, or that was cut out for me, was to look at the taxi industry and the economic structure of the taxi industry.
And it turned out I was the first person who'd ever done that.
We did a survey, and I put together all this information.
And I wasn't quite sure what to make out of all of it, but that was the start.
I wrote a couple of articles then while still at this firm.
What was the name of that firm?
The firm was then called General Research Corporation and it's now changed its name to something else.
And they're back doing, I think, largely World War III stuff.
They tried the urban stuff for four or five years and had a subsidiary that went off and did a lot of police work.
But two things happened in the end of 1970, 1969.
One was
Let me do that later.
But one was that UCLA called me and asked me if I had been interested in doing a doctoral degree because they had a traffic safety, 10 traffic safety fellowships from then.
The US Department of Health, HEW then.
And they couldn't find enough people.
Nobody wanted to take a traffic safety fellowship.
And the requirements were not on us at all.
And it was a lot of money.
So in the end of the 60s, it was $3,000 plus tuition.
And all you had to do was take one traffic safety course a year.
It was not exactly a terrible thing.
So I had been putting that off, putting it off.
I had been thinking sort of about going back for a doctor.
This came through.
At the same time, the firm I was with got a contract in Watts in East Los Angeles.
to do, it was right after the Watts riots, to do a major study of their transportation needs.
These two incidents were obviously very fortuitous.
I went back to UCLA with the grant and the job, had a wonderful time, became, quote, a transportation expert.
And when I was finishing up, my old boss at this firm called Leon Cole and said, or came to me and said, Leon Cole's putting together a program in Texas.
Would you be interested?
And they interviewed me, etc., etc.
I came down for the practice, to practice anything.
I mean, I couldn't imagine.
My mother and father had been here during the war, and my mother had horrible stories about Texas, Paris, Texas.
And I came down, of course, fell in love with Austin.
And I was offered the job.
I took it.
What year was that?
It was the spring of 72.
I was offered the job.
I came here in the fall, September of 72.
Mm-hmm.
And what have you been doing since?
Well, I'm not sure I'm not going to edit this out of the tape, but I did not come with my dissertation.
I was ABD, and I screwed around for three years.
It wasn't that I screwed around so much.
For example, Leon left like ten months later, and he had a big contract.
Well, at that time it was big, I don't know, $10,000 or $15,000 from the college coordinating board to do something about transportation.
He hadn't done a thing, and he hadn't spent much of the money either, so I got that grant.

And I used it to study something that I had gotten very interested in, which was low capital measures to deal with traffic congestion, traffic congestion in cities, not focusing on all sorts of planning issues as opposed to signalization and traffic lights and curbs and gutters, looking at land use and transit and bus lanes and how that would affect it.
Subsequently, I bid on and won a very large grant

In the end it was about a quarter of a million dollars over three years from the National Cooperative Highway Research Program of the National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences to do a major study all across the United States of these same kind of more socially based traffic control measures.
And for a long time I did that and then I got back into doing the stuff I had done when I had been with this company which was looking at
the role of the taxi, which by this time had come to be called paratransit.
And that became about mid-70s that flared up again.
I did a lot of work from the National Academy putting together conferences on paratransit.
Wrote a lot on that.
Segwayed from there into doing a lot of stuff on the elderly and handicapped, because though it's not commonly known,
the elderly and the disadvantaged are the major customers of taxes.
And it's pretty, in many cases, it's evenly divided between very rich people and very poor people.
It's people who don't have cars.
And the majority of people who don't have cars are either business people in some other city who don't have their own car, or poor people in their own city who don't have their own car.
And so I think through the decade of the 70s, I became...
I think one of the country's leading experts on the elderly and handicapped and our paratransit notes.
I haven't kept up as much on the traffic congestion stuff.
In part, I do some, but not a lot.

Then in the early 80s, I got real interested in the impact of the demographic changes in society on transportation, particularly to workers and the working wife, and even more than that, the working mother, which has just been
The incredible social change of this generation, this century really, is not just the number of women in the workforce, it's the number of women and young children who are in the workforce.
I know it's astonishing, and this society is just not ready for it.
It needs the workers.
It clearly needs those women and the jobs they do, but it is absolutely not structured to respond to their needs.
We talk about valuing the family, and even feminists are rediscovering the family.

and I sort of agree with Betty for Dan a little bit, that the feminists, they concentrated upper-middle-class women and forgot about the rest of everybody, and they concentrated women that didn't have children and whose children were already grown.

But every country in the world, whether they're socialist or right-wing, some of them try to actively prevent women from entering the labor force because of social or cultural reasons, but those that allow women in the labor force
recognize that it's important for the family that you provide proper child care and family support.
So it's not just true of the Scandinavian countries.
We hear a lot about it.
It's true of every country I've ever dealt with.
People realize that children are their future resource.
And whether you want women working or you don't want women working, you realize that if they go out to work, you have to do something about your children, and you have to do
At a minimum, you have to do something about their children.
And better, you have to have all kinds of maternity and maternity policies, and you have to have family leave policies and part-time work.
And this society is absolutely not responsive.
Obviously, I can't deal with all that.
What I've tended to deal with in the last five or six years is transportation.
How well, what kind, all these new travel patterns, all these new work patterns,
clearly must create new travel patterns.
And leisure patterns.
Exactly.
And how do we respond?
How does the transportation planning process respond to them?
That's what I wanted to look at.
And first I started from a much more technical view, and I really resisted the easy psychology of the day or Life magazine kind of approach to, you know, Time magazine just did a thing on child care.
I mean, real tripping light kind of stuff.
No, I really tried to focus in on what transportation planning models entailed
how they dealt with the employment of women and the employment of women with children, how they dealt with how a household divided responsibilities and how that might impact travel patterns.
If you know anything about it, you discover that none of the models that anybody uses is at all responsive.
Lately, I've gone away from being so concerned with what modelers do, because you really have to be
fairly sophisticated in a very technical way to understand what's in a model, and nobody cares.
And I've been addressing the larger policy issues.
In the early 70s, then, when I first got interested in this, I wrote a grant to the German Marshall Fund of the United States.

And with support from, you know, you just halfway luck into these things, and it's an idea whose time has come, with support from the Dutch government and the French government, I got this grant, I did a survey here in the United States, I did a survey, the French government did it for me, but it was the same survey in Lyon, France, and the Dutch government did it in Rotterdam, so we have, you know,

small scale, 200 families, maybe 50 families in each place, but very detailed questions about what they did with their kids, and how they've impacted their travel behavior, and how their household responsibilities.
And subsequent to the German Marshall Fund, I had a National Science Foundation NSF grant.
I had, allied with that, CNRS, which is the French equivalent.
It was a joint grant from the French NSF and our NSF.
Then I had a Rockefeller grant.
I've had some university research grants, so I've been funded on this now going on five years.
Funding runs out right about now, and I have a couple of flyers in the iron.
I'm not real worried because I think it's such a sexy topic, if I can use that word, that I think there's more money in it.
Do you get paid a salary as well?
Oh, no, of course not.
No, but I do get to go live in France.
I live in the 8283.
I live in France almost a year, a community between France and Holland.
I've spent the last five summers for two or three months in my apartment in Paris.
It's the first year since 1982 that I have not been in Paris for the summer.
Maybe that's why I got the impression that you're here next.
I'm here in the semester usually.
See, 82, 83, I was not.
I was off, so I was in Paris.
What courses do you normally attend?
I don't teach any transportation courses much anymore because there's not as much demand as you might think.
There's always a few people who are really interested, but not enough to sustain...
There are a lot of jobs in transportation.
Oh, that's the only reason I think I get some of the students.
What I've noticed is, and again, I'm not sure I'm going to do this in the record, the best students are not particularly interested in transportation.
And quite often, I get the worst students.
Oh, dear.
Yeah, there's tons of jobs.
People call me all the time looking for jobs.
I can place anybody a job tomorrow afternoon.
Not necessarily in Austin.
No, no.
But that's been our experience today, I know.
No, no.
It's definitely true.
But they're still not interested.
And the reason is, I've had a lot of time to think about this, and a lot of educators and I have talked about it.
I think it's not technical enough for engineers.
I mean, there are technical components in the modeling stuff.
But that's not technical enough for engineers, so it's not held very high in the engineering and the CE department.
They have their problems filling their transportation courses, too, in CE all across the country.
And in planning schools, it's too technical.
It's too quantitative.
You have to understand too many quantitative kinds of things.
And the people who are drawn from the social sciences to transportation are drawn often to the idea of a rail system, in which I don't believe, in which most academics don't believe.
In any case, when they discover there's no easy answers and it might be to deal with the transportation problems in the city, you might have to do 27 different things from carpools to bus lanes to...
a lot of people turn right and red lights to it.
You know, also, I mean, you have to have a whole sort of package of viable options, and you have to approach everything.
Americans in general, you know, want a simple solution, and they discover the rail system quickly, a quick, simple solution.
The rail system is probably not the answer, and even if it would solve some of the problems, it wouldn't solve a whole bunch of other problems.
A lot of people come in thinking that rail systems are the answer to the problems of poor people or handicapped people, and then they're shocked to realize that
You know, that that's not true at all in New York or Chicago or Atlanta or any of those places.
And so when the quick answer goes away, a lot of them lose interest.
Plus, on top of that, they have to learn all this complicated modeling stuff.
And of course, this is not a program like MIT or Northwestern.
You don't end up having to do a lot of modeling.
When Alan was here, he taught some here.
Mostly we ship our students over to the CE department to take the modeling stuff.
But if you have to count anything, do any equations at all, and they've already lost the charisma of the subject is gone.
So I rarely teach transportation courses.
What I do teach is three out of the five or six required courses in the program.
I do that because for many years I did not.
All through the 70s, I taught only seminars when I wanted to.
I saw very few of the students.
There's hundreds of students, probably more than hundreds, who went through this program without ever taking a course with me.
What courses do you teach now?
Now I teach Introduction to Planning, which is some planning history, some planning theory.
It's very much a skills course, writing skills, graphic skills.
I co-teach that with Peter Koltman, who of course has the graphic skills.
I teach the computer part, I teach the writing part, I teach some of the history.
Peter and I share the history.
And we sort of cover everything, sort of introduction to everything, library use.
Also, I teach financing public services, which is about a third of the microeconomics course and then the traditional public finance course.
I also teach, in the spring, I teach planning methods, which is all of the population projection methods, the regional economic methods.
forecasting and so forth.
Well, that's quite a lot.
And computer stuff, yeah.
And then in the spring, I usually also teach one of my seminars.

In the last couple of years, I've taught the seminar either on single parents, or this summer, for example, I taught the seminar on the problems of women alone at three times in their life, the displaced housewife, the elderly widow, and the single woman with children.
And it was a small course, five or six, but very successful.
And I'm enjoying it.
I enjoy that.
For a long time, I wouldn't even teach my research stuff in my seminars, because I felt that there's so much else to cover.
And I think that was a big mistake, because I have an enthusiasm about, everybody has enthusiasm about their research that they don't necessarily have about their planning efforts.
I'm the person in this program who's largely responsible for our emphasis on writing skills.
Dowell Myers was here, and I
I went off to a seminar at MIT, taught by Louise Dunlap in 1980-something.
Other people still talk about it.
I got into new writing pedagogy, which you may know something about.
You don't write outlines, because writing is thinking.
And you legitimize the thinking process, and you say, OK, at some point,
you have to stop and revise, and the hard work comes from revising.
So you have to teach revising skills, and you have to legitimate thinking and writing, because that's the way people do it.
Writing is hard work, it's practice.
Nobody was born being a good writer.
Some people have higher skill levels, but the way you get better is to practice and write over and over and over and over and over again.
You don't have to worry about your audience and all of that.
So I've been writing with numbers.
I've been very, very...
forceful in that.
My other colleagues can recognize it, and they tell me all the time that they can see it.
The negative part, they can see improvement in student writing.
I mean, there's no doubt at all.
In two years, and it's not just me, of course.
Obviously, the other faculty members have had input.
But because I teach so many of the required courses, and because I stress this all the time, stress what things look like ever since the Macintosh has come along.
Graphics have to be good looking.
Things have to look good, as well as the content.
If they look at it, there's a chance they might work well.
Well, it's a possibility with both.
What I've noticed in my years is that
People are real busy out in the real world, and they don't have a lot of time, and they make snap judges, and they do judge a book by its cover, and all of that sort of thing.
And it's not fair, and students tell me it's not fair.
They tell me it's not fair to grade that way, and it's not fair that the world works that way.
But in point of fact, I have seen junk proposals.

I've been on National Academy of Science committees who are the worst, not the worst, but certainly far from the best proposal won, because it was good looking, it was printed as opposed to Xerox, they had colored paper.

there's nothing there avoided it look good a lot of flash so i think you got to teach flash and substance at the same time and you know my fellow faculty see it because the papers get better and better looking and it's much slower they get better and better in terms of content and the neck the downside of it is it takes an incredible amount of time and there's a lot of students and typically to begin with
Later, often they come back and say, I'm glad you did that.
And I've had them cycling through for the last five years, once they've been out in the workforce, coming back and saying, oh, that's the best thing.
I'm so glad you did that.
But when you're doing it to them, a lot of them have gone all the way through undergraduate school without ever writing an essay or doing anything but taking machine-graded tests.
And they've forgotten how.
So it's troublesome.
Well, I've worked with some of the people at UT Arlington and the Urban Studies Center, and I think they do some nice work.
They're real aggressive, and they're an urban area, a real urban area, and I think they look...
I haven't seen a lot of work from them, but what I've seen, I think it's first rate.
They did some stuff on interlocal cooperation contracts between governments.
They did some work, and they let me use their database on private contracting by...
by local governments.
In terms of what they're teaching, I have to confess I don't know.
I only know them as, in that limited capacity, seeing them at APA meetings and knowing some of their work, which their work I find fine.
I think I have a better feeling about what goes on at AAM, though you may not think so.
I think I have a good sense of

Well, I think I have a sense of what you teach, and it seems to me that in certain areas you're far better than anyone in the state, and that is in areas of land use, traditional planning, and history.
You have real strength there, a real strong commitment to that.
Students come out really knowing what they're doing.
My impression is that
If you come out with a master's from A&M, you can walk right in and take the AICP and pass it.
I don't mean an exaggeration, but I think you actually have a higher success rate.
Well, you may not have a higher success rate than our students, but I think fewer of our students take it.
So I think if as many of our students took it as yours take it, I think that you would have a higher pass rate.
I think you're more geared toward that.
Of course, we have it.
Also, I know a lot about that various faculty members make an active practice of going to communities and doing field work studies, doing studies for communities.
I don't know.
I must confess, whether you get paid for them, or you go out and seek a client, or you just do them, I don't know.

I mean, often I even know from somebody on the faculty that somebody's doing a study like that, or I'm in some small community or something, and I hear that, yeah, I need something there, and we've done that.
So I get a real sense of public service and real field work training for the students.
There is a lot of that.
In fact, I think almost too much.
Well, maybe.
That's possible.
See, I don't know.
I would prefer to see it more academically.
Well, now, I don't know.
It's hard to say.
I would say that makes you a little more narrow than we are.
But certainly in the area that you're strong, you're really strong.
And traditionally, that's been good material for first jobs.
Our students agitated us to do more of that.
And it's not my particular interest.
I'm not saying I necessarily disagree with it.
But I'm not going to turn into a land use and zoning person tomorrow.
You know, I do think if one of our students is competing with one of your students for an entry-level job, our student is in a disadvantage.
On the other hand, I think that's what it looks like in paper.

I'm not sure that we don't challenge... with the academic stuff, that we don't challenge the students so that over the long run they may have... they may be more responsive to less structured situations.
When you're an entry-level person, you're in a very structured situation.
What I try to tell students is...
Sure, you should have a set of skills that get you a nice first-level job, okay?
But things change.
The computers you're learning today, five years from now, are going to be outdated.
Somebody's going to invent something else.
I mean, you can't...
If you want to stay a computer person, okay, then no, you're going to have to keep up that way.
Otherwise, take it... You have the advantage of lots of schools don't put you out as computer literate as we do.
Go out, fly with that, find out what you want to do, and then use your other skills, your thinking, your analytical skills, you know, to develop and to get somewhere.
I remember when there was a great push for all planets to learn Fortran.
Yeah.
And I resisted that like crazy, and I...
very happy I did.
Well, interestingly, I went back and learned Pascal last year.
And I'm glad I did because I learned it in a very superficial way.
And I'm glad I did because I understand a lot of things about SAS and SPSS, about the computer programs.
But in general, I would say probably right now, not more than 10% of our students ever touch a mainframe.
and maybe less will over time, because now we have SPSS and SAS running on the micros, and the micros have horrendous memory.
On the other hand, I think that if you go out and you don't know how to run a micro, you should have been taught that.
That's very different from Fortran.
I mean, micros are like typewriters, or maps.
I mean, they're part of the technical skill
toolkit that you have to have when you go out into the real world.
And it's very true to me that some of our students have been hired solely on those grounds.
Now, that's fine.
You know, what I say to them is you've got to make sure that you don't get stuck being the computer person when you really want to be a planner.
And we have a couple of students, one who's resisted.
I think he's, I'm not sure, but I think he's just gone to work for the county.

he's just a computer whiz and he put our whole lab together and he's made money over the last year since he's graduated big money doing computing consulting so what he wants to do he wants to be a planner and he wants to use the computer but he doesn't want to be the computer whiz and so he's turned down a number of jobs where he would have that either had nothing to do with planning or where he would simply be the computer hack for people so that's difficult and i'm
But in that sense, he sees firmly what the problem is.
And if you're too good at that, then they'll take away the planning, the substantive stuff.
So you have to watch that.
Hopefully we're training people who can deal with the substance as well as some of the preference.
Mm-hmm.
Good.
